lines.text: Enter BERTRAM and DIANA

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: They told me that your name was Fontibell.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: No, my good lord, Diana.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Titled goddess; And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul, In your fine frame hath love no quality? If quick fire of youth light not your mind, You are no maiden, but a monument: When you are dead, you should be such a one As you are now, for you are cold and stem; And now you should be as your mother was When your sweet self was got.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: She then was honest.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: So should you be.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: No: My mother did but duty; such, my lord, As you owe to your wife.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: No more o' that; I prithee, do not strive against my vows: I was compell'd to her; but I love thee By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever Do thee all rights of service.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Ay, so you serve us Till we serve you; but when you have our roses, You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves And mock us with our bareness.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: How have I sworn!

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth, But the plain single vow that is vow'd true. What is not holy, that we swear not by, But take the High'st to witness: then, pray you, tell me, If I should swear by God's great attributes, I loved you dearly, would you believe my oaths, When I did love you ill? This has no holding, To swear by him whom I protest to love, That I will work against him: therefore your oaths Are words and poor conditions, but unseal'd, At least in my opinion.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Change it, change it; Be not so holy-cruel: love is holy; And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts That you do charge men with. Stand no more off, But give thyself unto my sick desires, Who then recover: say thou art mine, and ever My love as it begins shall so persever.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: I see that men make ropes in such a scarre That we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I'll lend it thee, my dear; but have no power To give it from me.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Will you not, my lord?

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: It is an honour 'longing to our house, Bequeathed down from many ancestors; Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world In me to lose.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: Mine honour's such a ring: My chastity's the jewel of our house, Bequeathed down from many ancestors; Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world In me to lose: thus your own proper wisdom Brings in the champion Honour on my part, Against your vain assault.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Here, take my ring: My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine, And I'll be bid by thee.

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber-window: I'll order take my mother shall not hear. Now will I charge you in the band of truth, When you have conquer'd my yet maiden bed, Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me: My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them When back again this ring shall be deliver'd: And on your finger in the night I'll put Another ring, that what in time proceeds May token to the future our past deeds. Adieu, till then; then, fail not. You have won A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.
Exit

lines.speaker: diana
lines.text: For which live long to thank both heaven and me! You may so in the end. My mother told me just how he would woo, As if she sat in 's heart; she says all men Have the like oaths: he had sworn to marry me When his wife's dead; therefore I'll lie with him When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid, Marry that will, I live and die a maid: Only in this disguise I think't no sin To cozen him that would unjustly win.
Exit
